all_paragraphs: Coding interviews often tend to ask a pattern program to test the candidates.
Usually, in an interview process lasting four rounds, the first round tends to be one programming round, and there is a probability that one of the questions asked could be a pattern program.

Pattern programming is when you are given a specific pattern design question often, with an asterisk (*) or numbers or letters, and you to program that design with the help of iterative looping statements.
In this article, we will uncover the ways through which we can solve these problems and understand the theory behind these programming patterns.

I use to solve most of my pattern programs using Java programming a few years ago, but python is just as easy or maybe even slightly easier. So, python will be the language of choice for this article.
However, the language used will not matter much, and only the interesting logic behind solving these problems is important. Today, we will be looking at a few of these basic questions.
So, without further ado, let us get our hands dirty and start coding!
The above pattern is the first type of question that we will solve in this article. Most of these pattern type questions can be solved with two or three iteration operations quite easily.

On closer observation, you can notice that after the first number is printed the cursor jumps to the next line, then after the printing of 2 numbers the cursor again moves to the next line, and so on.
Our logic for solving this pattern will be quite simple. We will have 5 rows, and then we will move the cursor subsequently after the printing of the numbers equal to its row number.
By this, I mean that for the first row, 1 number will be printed, the second row will print 2 numbers, and so on.

The Final pattern program that we will analyze how to solve today is the full pyramid with an Asterisk. You can feel free to try this out with numbers as well on your own for a better conceptual understanding.

We will use an extra variable for the calculation of the spaces required according to the problem. The computations for the rows and columns will remain almost the same as processed in the previous pattern programming questions.

In this pattern program, we have used the number ’n’ for input from the user. The ‘k’ variable is used for calculating the number of spaces accordingly. Once the number of spaces is calculated, we will subtract the remaining spaces. The ‘i’th row and ‘j’th column are calculated similarly to all the other pattern programs.
In this article, we managed to cover most of the basic pattern programming questions that might be asked in interviews and how to solve them systematically.
There are lots of patterns possible in the world of programming, and there are tons of patterns more that you can construct by using a programming language of your choice.
If you guys are interested in these, then I will also make a part-2 covering more such similar pattern programming questions that could potentially be asked in interviews.

Also, the viewers can feel free to let me know if you have any queries regarding the solutions to the problems that we solved today. Also, feel free to suggest more question patterns that you think I should cover in the future.
